learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate broad knowledge relating to international relations and strategic studies issues
Evaluate the strength of particular theoretical approaches to strategic studies
Assess different perspectives and approaches to the use and limits of military power as an instrument of influence in world politics
Apply your knowledge of key issues for a better understanding of current affairs

assessments.task_description:
Seminar participation forms a crucial component of this course. As such, ten percent of your grade is attached to this assessment activity. Participation is not about making the most insightful comments or getting answers to questions right. It is about airing ideas, asking questions, and contributing to a productive classroom discussion, befitting of postgraduate study. This part of the assessment is a great opportunity for you to boost your overall grade, as students who attend all classes and always chip in with some ideas or thoughts will get full marks. If you attend all classes but never say anything, you will receive no points for this item of assessment. Conversely, if you attend all classes and always contribute, you will get the full 10 percent. The course coordinator and tutor will keep a record of who contributes. 

As there are 12 seminars but only 10 points awarded in total for seminar participation, students can miss two seminars without penalty. 

Students who are unwell or have extenuating circumstances for non-attendance can email the Course Coordinator Dr Andrew Phillips (andrew.phillips@uq.edu.au) with medical or other documentation. Make up work will be assigned in lieu by the Course Coordinator for students to be assigned marks when they cannot attend.

PLEASE NOTE: Students who cannot regularly attend the 4-5:50pm Thursday time slot should reconsider their enrolment in this class.

Assessment tasks are intended to evaluate a student’s abilities, skills, and knowledge. Unless explicitly stated otherwise in the assessment instructions, assessments are to be completed without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT). Failure to comply with this direction may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be asked to address a short essay question engaging core themes covered in the first two weeks of the teaching semester. The essay question will be available via Blackboard on the first day of the semester.

Assessment tasks are intended to evaluate a student’s abilities, skills, and knowledge. Unless explicitly stated otherwise in the assessment instructions, assessments are to be completed without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT). Failure to comply with this direction may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The essay must be submitted via TURNITIN on the POLS7228 Blackboard site. TURNITIN cross checks tutorial and essay papers submitted in the course and with those submitted in POLS7228 in previous semesters. Instances of suspected plagiarism are required to be forwarded to the School's Integrity Officer.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will select one topic from a list of research essay questions that will be released in the early weeks of the semester via Blackboard. The essay should be 2400 words long, with a plus or minus 10 percent margin. Any essays longer will suffer a 10% reduction in the total possible grade.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction - What is Strategic Studies?

This seminar will introduce the scope of the course, teaching methods and assessment. Substantively, we will discuss the meaning of 'strategy' and the distinctiveness of a 'strategic studies' approach to studying global security issues.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction - What is Strategic Studies? This seminar will introduce the scope of the course, teaching methods and assessment. Substantively, we will discuss the meaning of 'strategy' and the distinctiveness of a 'strategic studies' approach to studying global security issues.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Force, Strategy, Influence and War

This seminar considers the question: what are the uses and limits of military power as a means of political influence in world politics? We consider the varied nature of military power as a political resource, and evaluate when, where and under what circumstances it can be deployed to advance agents' political goals.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Force, Strategy, Influence and War This seminar considers the question: what are the uses and limits of military power as a means of political influence in world politics? We consider the varied nature of military power as a political resource, and evaluate when, where and under what circumstances it can be deployed to advance agents' political goals.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: US Grand Strategy and International Order

This seminar considers the legacy of the Trump revolution on US grand strategy, and its potential impact on the liberal international order that the US has previously sponsored as the centrepiece of its grand strategy since 1945. Prospective strategic implications of US global retrenchment will form a key focus of discussion.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 3: US Grand Strategy and International Order
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: US Grand Strategy and International Order This seminar considers the legacy of the Trump revolution on US grand strategy, and its potential impact on the liberal international order that the US has previously sponsored as the centrepiece of its grand strategy since 1945. Prospective strategic implications of US global retrenchment will form a key focus of discussion.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Chinese Grand Strategy

This seminar considers the evolving grand strategy of China - a rising superpower and potential hegemonic successor to the United States. China's economic statecraft will form a focal point of discussion.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Chinese Grand Strategy This seminar considers the evolving grand strategy of China - a rising superpower and potential hegemonic successor to the United States. China's economic statecraft will form a focal point of discussion.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Australia and Grand Strategy

In this seminar, we consider the challenges that Australia faces in formulating and implementing a grand strategy in a more contested and uncertain Indo-Pacific strategic environment. The management of the ANZUS alliance will form a focal point of discussion.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Australia and Grand Strategy In this seminar, we consider the challenges that Australia faces in formulating and implementing a grand strategy in a more contested and uncertain Indo-Pacific strategic environment. The management of the ANZUS alliance will form a  focal point of discussion.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Power Politics in Maritime Asia

In this seminar, we consider power politics in the maritime domain of the Indo-Pacific. We consider the present nature of the US-dominated Asian security order, the evolving regional military balance, and the ways in which Great Powers are now contesting that order. We also consider the distinctiveness of strategic rivalry in a maritime context, and the scope for managing regional power transitions short of armed conflict. The longrunning Taiwan Straits dispute will form a focal point of discussion.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Power Politics in Maritime Asia In this seminar, we consider power politics in the maritime domain of the Indo-Pacific. We consider the present nature of the US-dominated Asian security order, the evolving regional military balance, and the ways in which Great Powers are now contesting that order. We also consider the distinctiveness of strategic rivalry in a maritime context, and the scope for managing regional power transitions short of armed conflict. The longrunning Taiwan Straits dispute will form a focal point of discussion.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Nuclear Deterrence and Assurance in Asia

This week we focus on the raft of challenges now undermining the global nuclear non-proliferation order. In particular, we focus on the increasingly complex US-China deterrence relationship. We also consider America's increasingly strained extended nuclear assurance relations with key Asian allies, and the prospective longevity of the US nuclear security umbrella in Northeast Asia.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 7: Nuclear Deterrence and Assurance in Asia
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Nuclear Deterrence and Assurance in Asia This week we focus on the raft of challenges now undermining the global nuclear non-proliferation order. In particular, we focus on the increasingly complex US-China deterrence relationship. We also consider America's increasingly strained extended nuclear assurance relations with key Asian allies, and the prospective longevity of the US nuclear security umbrella in Northeast Asia.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Power Politics and the war in Ukraine

This week we continue our investigation of power politics in the current global order. We shift our focus from Asia to Europe, considering Great Power rivalry and the ongoing order transition in Eastern Europe and in post-Soviet Eurasia. The ongoing war in Ukraine will be our primary focus of attention.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 8: Power Politics and the war in Ukraine
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Power Politics and the war in Ukraine This week we continue our investigation of power politics in the current global order. We shift our focus from Asia to Europe, considering Great Power rivalry and the ongoing order transition in Eastern Europe and in post-Soviet Eurasia. The ongoing war in Ukraine will be our primary focus of attention.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: 'Grey Area' Conflicts and Information Warfare

This week we consider the strategic challenges that 'grey area' conflicts pose to international peace and security. The use of information warfare as a means of corroding the adversary's cohesion and resolve will form a particular focus of discussion.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: 'Grey Area' Conflicts and Information Warfare This week we consider the strategic challenges that 'grey area' conflicts pose to international peace and security. The use of information warfare as a means of corroding the adversary's cohesion and resolve will form a particular focus of discussion.
Mid-Semester Break Mid-semester break - no classes.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Asymmetric Warfare

This week we consider the challenges of asymmetric warfare. Asymmetric conflicts are characterised by significant disparities in adversaries' conventional military capabilities, and a resulting resort to asymmetric tactics (e.g. guerrilla warfare, terrorism, rebel state-building) by insurgents as they seek to overthrow counterinsurgents and establish a new political order. A range of contemporary case studies will inform our discussion.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Asymmetric Warfare This week we consider the challenges of asymmetric warfare. Asymmetric conflicts are characterised by significant disparities in adversaries' conventional military capabilities, and a resulting resort to asymmetric tactics (e.g. guerrilla warfare, terrorism, rebel state-building) by insurgents as they seek to overthrow counterinsurgents and establish a new political order. A range of contemporary case studies will inform our discussion.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Emerging Technologies and Strategic Competition

This week we will examine the impact of emerging technologies on contemporary Great Power strategic competition. The legal and ethical as well as the strategic implications of emerging technologies on global order will also be considered.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Emerging Technologies and Strategic Competition This week we will examine the impact of emerging technologies on contemporary Great Power strategic competition. The legal and ethical as well as the strategic implications of emerging technologies on global order will also be considered.

learning_activities.topic:
Independent Study

Independent study - no classes.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Independent Study Independent study - no classes.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Strategy and the Future(s)of War

We conclude the course by considering the key security challenges that are likely to define world politics in the coming decades. Revisiting the course's central theme, we will use this opportunity to reflect on the likely future relevance of military power as an instrument of political influence in world politics. Is war obsolete, enduring or in the process of transformation? Equally, how might transformative pressures (e.g. accelerating climate change, the rise of disruptive technologies, the resurgence of non-Western Great Powers) impact on the relationship between military power and political influence in the emerging global order?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

Equally, how might transformative pressures (e.g. accelerating climate change, the rise of disruptive technologies, the resurgence of non-Western Great Powers) impact on the relationship between military power and political influence in the emerging global order?
